questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness upon rising from his chair at work. The patient has had progressive cough, shortness of breath, fever, and chills for 6 days but did not seek medical attention for these symptoms. He appears distressed, flushed, and diaphoretic. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 122 kg (269 lb); BMI is 42 kg/m2. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 129/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 91/50 mm Hg when supine. Crackles and bronchial breath sounds are heard over the right posterior hemithorax. A 2/6 midsystolic blowing murmur is heard along the left upper sternal border. Examination shows diffuse diaphoresis, flushed extremities, and dullness to percussion over the right posterior hemithorax. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Multiple nurses and physicians have been unable to attain intravenous access. A large-bore central venous catheter is inserted into the right internal jugular vein by standard sterile procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer intravenous levofloxacin
Echocardiogram
Bronchoscopy
CT scan of the chest
X-ray of the chest
Administer intravenous norepinephrine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous levofloxacin is an empiric antibiotic regimen used for inpatient treatment of community-acquired pneumonia. However, this patient's condition has progressed to septic shock, which requires immediate intravenous empiric antibiotic treatment with vancomycin and cefepime. Furthermore, because this patient just underwent an emergent CVC placement, a different step is indicated at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram can be used to identify the position of certain CVCs (e.g., if they are positioned in the right atrium) and to rule out particular complications following CVC placement (e.g., pneumomediastinum). However, an echocardiogram is not routinely performed after a CVC is inserted.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy and bronchoalveolar lavage may be indicated if this patient's pneumonia does not respond to broad-spectrum antibiotics. Nevertheless, given his recent CVC placement, another step is more important to conduct at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest can identify catheter positioning and can be used to evaluate immediate complications following CVC placement. However, a CT scan should not be performed on hemodynamically unstable patients.

E) CORRECT:

Imaging is required following jugular or subclavian central venous line insertion to rule out potentially life-threatening complications. Chest x-ray or ultrasound is used to confirm whether the distal end of a CVC is properly placed within the superior vena cava at the level of the carina, which is critical given the increased risk of complications associated with improper CVC placement. Pneumothorax is one of the most common complications, occurring at a rate of ∼ 3%. Other immediate complications may also develop, such as pneumomediastinum, bleeding, cardiac tamponade, arterial puncture, and arrhythmias. Long-term complications include venous thrombosis, infection, vessel wall erosion, and catheter migration.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (AP view)

There is a central venous catheter in the left subclavian vein. Its tip is resting against the wall of the superior vena cava (arrows).

When placed correctly, the catheter's distal end should lie in the center of the lumen of the superior vena cava, at the level of the carina.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous norepinephrine administration would be indicated if this patient does not respond appropriately to intravenous fluid resuscitation through his CVC. However, given his recent CVC placement, another step is more important to conduct at this time.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has septic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, flushed skin, fever) due to untreated pneumonia. Insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) allows for intravenous fluid resuscitation but the catheter must be carefully placed.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with septic shock due to community-acquired pneumonia. He has received 3 liters of crystalloid but continues to have a mean arterial pressure of 55 mm Hg (reference range, 70–110). Central venous access is required for resuscitation and administration of vasopressors.
Which one of the following practices will most reliably reduce the risks associated with central venous catheterization?

choices.text: Use the left subclavian site, located with anatomical landmarks, and send blood cultures every 3 days to screen for infection
Use the right femoral site, located with anatomical landmarks, and remove the catheter after 7 days, with replacement of a new catheter as needed
Use the right subclavian site, located with real-time ultrasound guidance, and change the catheter over a wire if the patient develops a fever and redness at the site of insertion
Use the left internal jugular site after marking the insertion site using ultrasound, and change the catheter over a wire every 7 days
Use the right internal jugular site, located with real-time ultrasound guidance, and assess daily for continued need for the catheter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided visualization reduces the rates of inadvertent arterial puncture and pneumothorax. Anatomical landmarks should be used in conjunction with ultrasound but are variable enough that they should not be used alone.

Site placement or location can affect complication rates as well. The subclavian site is associated with higher rates of pneumothorax but lower rates of arterial puncture and infection.

All central venous catheters increase the patient’s risk for bloodstream infections. Routine screening blood cultures have not been shown to be beneficial, and they create unneeded cost.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided visualization reduces the rates of inadvertent arterial puncture and pneumothorax. Anatomical landmarks should be used in conjunction with ultrasound but are variable enough that they should not be used alone.

All central venous catheters increase the patient’s risk for bloodstream infections. The best way to avoid these infections is to assess the need for the catheter and to remove it as soon as it is no longer needed. Lines should not be routinely changed over a wire or removed and replaced, because this does not reduce the risk of infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided visualization reduces the rates of inadvertent arterial puncture and pneumothorax. Real-time visualization is superior to simply looking with ultrasound and then marking the site. Of note, this technique is more difficult with subclavian catheter placement.

Site placement or location can affect complication rates as well. The subclavian site is associated with higher rates of pneumothorax but lower rates of arterial puncture and infection.

All central venous catheters increase the patient’s risk for bloodstream infections. Lines should not be routinely changed over a wire or removed and replaced, because this does not reduce the risk of infection. If a catheter appears infected (i.e., there is erythema and tenderness at the site), it should be completely removed and not changed over a wire.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided visualization reduces the rates of inadvertent arterial puncture and pneumothorax. Anatomical landmarks should be used in conjunction with ultrasound but are variable enough that they should not be used alone.

All central venous catheters increase the patient’s risk for bloodstream infections. Lines should not be routinely changed over a wire or removed and replaced, because this does not reduce the risk of infection. If a catheter appears infected (i.e., there is erythema and tenderness at the site), it should be completely removed and not changed over a wire.

E) CORRECT:

Central venous catheterization is often necessary in the management of patients in the intensive care unit; however, it can have significant complications, including inadvertent arterial puncture or cannulization, pneumothorax, or bloodstream infection.

Ultrasound-guided visualization reduces the rates of inadvertent arterial puncture and pneumothorax. Real-time visualization is superior to simply looking with ultrasound and then marking the site. Of note, this technique is more difficult with subclavian catheter placement. Anatomical landmarks should be used in conjunction with ultrasound but are variable enough that they should not be used alone.

Site placement or location can affect complication rates as well. The internal jugular site is associated with lower rates of pneumothorax but higher rates of arterial puncture. The subclavian site is associated with higher rates of pneumothorax but lower rates of arterial puncture and infection. Generally, the internal jugular site is preferred for short-term use.

All central venous catheters increase the patient’s risk for bloodstream infections. The best way to avoid these infections is to assess the need for the catheter and to remove it as soon as it is no longer needed. Routine screening blood cultures have not been shown to be beneficial, and they create unneeded cost. Lines should not be routinely changed over a wire or removed and replaced, because this does not reduce the risk of infection. If a catheter appears infected (i.e., there is erythema and tenderness at the site), it should be completely removed and not changed over a wire.

Key learning point: The most effective approach to lowering the risk of complications associated with central venous catheterization is to use real-time ultrasound guidance to approach the internal jugular site and remove the line when it is no longer needed.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is being treated in the intensive care unit for septic shock. Antibiotics and vasopressors are being administered through a central venous catheter in the right internal jugular vein. The jugular venous catheter was inserted under sterile conditions within the past 24 hours.
The patient’s nurse informs you that she can only infuse through the proximal port and cannot aspirate blood from any of the ports. She has tried flushing the catheter multiple times without improved aspiration of blood.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Administer the medications through peripheral intravenous cannula
Retain the existing central venous catheter for infusions, and insert another central venous catheter to obtain blood
Remove the existing central venous catheter, and insert a new catheter in the right femoral vein
Change the existing central venous catheter over a guide wire
Insert a new catheter in a subclavian vein, and remove the existing central venous catheter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peripheral infusion of vasopressors is not recommended because it can lead to ischemia and tissue necrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Retaining the existing catheter and inserting a new one for blood draws increases the risk of infection because two central venous catheters will be in place.

C) INCORRECT:

The femoral vein is generally not a preferred site for central lines (unless there is suspicion of coagulopathy, as the inguinal area is an easily compressible site). Studies have shown higher rates of deep-vein thrombosis with femoral line placement than with internal jugular or subclavian line placement but have not confirmed the theory that this site is associated with a higher rate of central line-associated bloodstream infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Changing a line over a guide wire is not recommended because this approach has been associated with an increased risk of bloodstream infection.

E) CORRECT:

An occluded catheter may indicate thrombosis, kinking of the catheter, or abnormal anatomy of the vasculature. When the catheter permits infusion but blood cannot be aspirated, as in this case, the most likely cause is early thrombosis of the line. If there is concern for thrombosis, a new site of placement is appropriate as well as an ultrasound of the current vessel. Central venous catheters that neither infuse nor allow aspiration usually have a mechanical problem.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for an occluded central venous catheter in a patient who requires central venous access is to insert a new catheter in an alternate site.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with altered mental status and hypotension. Vital signs are BP, 78/45 mm Hg; P, 118; he appears dehydrated. Repeated attempts at peripheral IV access have been unsuccessful. Laboratory results show platelet count 52,000/μL and INR 2.3. The patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation and probable vasopressor support. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Ultrasound-guided internal jugular central venous catheter
Landmark-guided subclavian central venous catheter
Femoral central venous catheter
Peripherally inserted central catheter
Delay central access until coagulopathy corrected

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Failed peripheral access with impending vasopressor use and large-volume resuscitation are clear indications for central venous access. In coagulopathic patients, the internal jugular site is preferred because inadvertent arterial puncture is compressible and ultrasound guidance reduces complications.

B) INCORRECT:

The subclavian site traverses a noncompressible region; arterial injury or bleeding in a patient with thrombocytopenia and elevated INR is more hazardous.

C) INCORRECT:

The femoral site is compressible and sometimes chosen in coagulopathy or during ongoing CPR; however, it has higher rates of catheter-related infection and thrombosis and impedes mobilization.

D) INCORRECT:

PICC placement is not an emergent ED procedure and typically requires dedicated personnel and imaging confirmation. It delays definitive access for resuscitation and vasoactive infusions, which are urgently needed.

E) INCORRECT:

Delaying central access in a hemodynamically unstable patient requiring immediate intervention is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with distributive shock requires central venous access for vasopressor administration. During ultrasound-guided right internal jugular vein catheterization, venous flashback is obtained, and the guidewire begins to advance. The cardiac monitor shows intermittent ventricular ectopy starting at a depth of 18 cm that becomes more frequent as the wire is advanced. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Withdraw the guidewire until the rhythm returns to baseline
Proceed with dilator insertion
Immediately initiate ACLS protocols for ventricular dysrhythmia
Continue advancing to 25 cm while monitoring for persistent arrhythmias
Remove the guidewire and needle as a single unit and restart at a different site

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- When ventricular dysrhythmia occurs during guidewire advancement, the guidewire should be withdrawn until the rhythm returns to baseline. The arrhythmia is typically caused by the guidewire irritating the atrial or ventricular wall and, in most cases, the procedure can continue after withdrawal.

B) INCORRECT:

Proceeding with dilator insertion while the patient has ventricular ectopy from guidewire irritation is inappropriate and potentially dangerous. The arrhythmia must be addressed first, so another step is more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

ACLS protocols are reserved for persistent dysrhythmias that do not resolve with guidewire withdrawal. Initial management should focus on removing the irritating stimulus.

D) INCORRECT:

Advancing the guidewire beyond 20 cm increases the risk of triggering arrhythmias. Continuing to advance the guidewire in a patient with ventricular ectopy worsens the situation.

E) INCORRECT:

Complete removal is not necessary at this time. The dysrhythmia can usually be resolved by simply withdrawing the guidewire, allowing the procedure to continue without restarting at a different site.
